Mac and Cheese with Bacon

Jump to Recipe

Indulge in the ultimate comfort food with our Mac and Cheese with Bacon recipe! This creamy, cheesy delight is elevated by the savory crunch of crispy bacon, making it a favorite for both kids and adults alike. Whether you're looking for a quick weeknight dinner or a satisfying side dish for a gathering, this recipe is your go-to solution. With just a handful of ingredients like elbow macaroni, sharp cheddar cheese, and of course, delicious bacon, you can whip up this mouthwatering dish in no time. Join us as we guide you through this easy-to-follow recipe that promises to deliver a rich and flavorful experience with every bite. Let's dive into the world of cheesy goodness and discover how to make Mac and Cheese with Bacon that will impress your family and friends!

Ingredients

elbow macaroni

Elbow macaroni is a classic choice for mac and cheese due to its shape, which holds cheese sauce well. If you don't have elbow macaroni, you can substitute it with other small pasta shapes like shells, fusilli, or cavatappi. Make sure to cook it al dente to avoid mushy pasta.

cheddar cheese

Cheddar cheese provides a rich and sharp flavor. For variety, you can mix different types of cheddar (mild, sharp, or extra sharp) for complexity. Alternatively, you can use Monterey Jack, Gruyère, or a combination of cheeses. For extra creaminess, consider adding some cream cheese or mascarpone.

milk

Whole milk will give you the creamiest sauce, but you can use 2% milk or even a non-dairy milk (like oat or almond) if needed. Just be aware that non-dairy options might alter the flavor slightly. For an extra richness, you can replace some of the milk with heavy cream.

butter

Butter adds richness and flavor to the roux. If you're looking for a healthier alternative, you can use olive oil or a plant-based butter. For added flavor, consider using browned butter, which has a nutty taste that enhances the dish.

all-purpose flour

Flour is used to create the roux. If you need a gluten-free option, you can substitute all-purpose flour with gluten-free flour blends or cornstarch. When using cornstarch, mix it with a bit of cold milk first to prevent clumping.

bacon

Bacon adds a savory, smoky flavor to the dish. If you're looking for a healthier option, turkey bacon or pancetta can be used instead. For a vegetarian version, consider using smoked paprika or liquid smoke to mimic the bacon flavor without the meat.

salt

Salt enhances the overall flavor of the dish. If you're watching your sodium intake, consider using low-sodium or sea salt, and adjust to taste. You can also enhance flavor with other seasonings like garlic powder or onion powder.

pepper

Black pepper adds a bit of heat and depth. For a different flavor profile, try using white pepper for a milder taste or even cayenne pepper for some kick. Freshly cracked pepper is recommended for the best flavor.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Cook the Elbow Macaroni

    Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the 8 oz of elbow macaroni and cook according to the package instructions until al dente. Drain the macaroni and set it aside.
    Tip:
    To prevent the pasta from sticking together, add a splash of olive oil to the water.

  • Step 2: Cook the Bacon

    In a large skillet, cook 4 strips of bacon over medium heat until crispy, usually about 5-7 minutes. Once cooked, remove the bacon from the skillet, crumble it into small pieces, and set it aside. Important: Leave the bacon grease in the skillet to enhance the flavor of your cheese sauce!

  • Step 3: Make the Roux

    In the same skillet over medium heat, melt 2 tablespoons of butter in the bacon grease. Once melted, stir in 2 tablespoons of all-purpose flour and cook for about 1 minute to form a roux.
    Note:
    This roux is crucial for thickening your cheese sauce.

  • Step 4: Whisk in the Milk

    Slowly whisk in 2 cups of milk, stirring constantly to avoid lumps. Continue to stir for about 3-5 minutes or until the mixture thickens to a creamy consistency.
    Tip:
    If using cold milk, it helps to whisk it in gradually to prevent lumps.

  • Step 5: Add the Cheese and Seasonings

    Add 2 cups of shredded cheddar cheese, along with 1 teaspoon of salt and 1/2 teaspoon of pepper to the thickened milk mixture. Stir until the cheese is fully melted and the sauce is smooth. Expert Note: For an extra cheesy flavor, consider mixing different types of cheese like mozzarella or gouda.

  • Step 6: Combine Macaroni and Cheese Sauce

    Gently fold the cooked macaroni into the cheese sauce, stirring until all the pasta is well coated.
    Tip:
    If the sauce is too thick, you can add a little more milk until you reach your desired consistency.

  • Step 7: Serve and Garnish

    Serve the mac and cheese hot, topped with the crumbled bacon. Enjoy your delicious homemade mac and cheese! Bonus Tip: For a crispy topping, consider broiling the mac and cheese for 2-3 minutes after adding breadcrumbs on top.

Frequently Asked Questions

What type of macaroni should I use for mac and cheese?

Elbow macaroni is the classic choice for mac and cheese, but you can also use other pasta shapes like shells or cavatappi. Just make sure to cook it according to the package instructions.

How do I know when the bacon is crispy?

Cook the bacon over medium heat and watch for it to turn a deep, golden brown. It should sizzle and shrink in size. If you're unsure, you can take a small piece out and taste it!

What is a roux and how do I make it?

A roux is a mixture of fat (like butter) and flour used to thicken sauces. To make it, melt the butter in the skillet, then add the flour and stir for about a minute until it forms a paste. This will help thicken your cheese sauce.

How can I tell when my cheese sauce is thick enough?

The cheese sauce should coat the back of a spoon. If you dip a spoon in and run your finger along the back, it should leave a clear line. This usually takes about 3-5 minutes of stirring after adding the milk.

What if my cheese sauce is too thick?

If your cheese sauce ends up too thick, you can thin it out by adding a little more milk, a tablespoon at a time, and stirring until you reach the desired consistency.

Can I use different types of cheese?

Absolutely! While cheddar is traditional, you can mix in other cheeses like mozzarella, Gouda, or even pepper jack for a kick. Just remember that the melting properties of the cheese will affect the sauce.

How do I store leftovers?

Allow the mac and cheese to cool completely, then transfer it to an airtight container. It will last in the refrigerator for about 3-5 days. Reheat in the microwave or on the stovetop with a splash of milk to keep it creamy.

Is it safe to eat bacon that is slightly undercooked?

It's best to cook bacon until it is crispy to ensure any harmful bacteria are killed. If the bacon is chewy or rubbery, give it a little more time in the skillet.

What can I do to prevent the mac and cheese from becoming dry after cooking?

Make sure to coat the pasta well with the cheese sauce while it’s still hot. If you plan to bake it, consider covering it with foil to keep moisture in, and add a little extra milk or cheese to the sauce.

How can I make my mac and cheese more flavorful?

Besides the basic seasoning of salt and pepper, consider adding garlic powder, onion powder, or even a splash of hot sauce for extra flavor. You can also mix in vegetables like broccoli or spinach for added nutrition.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a gluten-free version, substitute the elbow macaroni with gluten-free pasta. Use gluten-free flour for the roux, and ensure that the bacon and cheese are free from any gluten-containing additives. For a lower-fat option, consider using a reduced-fat cheese and turkey bacon. Additionally, for a vegetarian version, you can omit the bacon and enhance the dish with roasted vegetables or sautéed mushrooms for added flavor.

Pairings

For an indulgent pairing, serve the mac and cheese with crispy fried chicken or a classic hamburger to complement the creamy cheese and salty bacon flavors. A light green salad with a tangy vinaigrette can provide a refreshing contrast. For beverages, consider pairing with a chilled lager or a crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc to cut through the richness of the dish. A light IPA can also work well for beer lovers.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the mac and cheese hot and bubbling in a cast-iron skillet or a colorful ceramic dish for a rustic presentation. Top generously with the crumbled bacon for added crunch and flavor. For an extra touch, sprinkle some chopped fresh parsley or chives on top for a pop of color and freshness. Consider offering additional toppings on the side, such as crispy fried onions, jalapeños for heat, or a drizzle of hot sauce for those who like a kick.

Description

Creamy mac and cheese with crispy bacon bits for a deliciously indulgent twist!

Ingredients

  • elbow macaroni: 8 oz
  • cheddar cheese: 2 cups shredded
  • milk: 2 cups
  • butter: 2 tablespoons
  • all-purpose flour: 2 tablespoons
  • bacon: 4 strips
  • salt: 1 teaspoon
  • pepper: 1/2 teaspoon
